entry.title: Combined summary - Time
entry.summary: The conversation centers around the security measures of breadwallet, an iOS application for Bitcoin storage, with suggestions ranging from delaying access to the wallet for increasing periods after each failed PIN attempt to recording the time of each failed attempt and not allowing further attempts until time has advanced past the previous attempt. Aaron Voisine announces that the upcoming release of breadwallet will use the height of the blockchain to enforce timed pin code lockouts. However, there are still concerns about the tamper resistance and zero on tamper hardware of breadwallet. Hearn argues that miners have in the past manipulated the timestamp to increase their gigahashes, and the chain could currently be dominated by a coalition of just two pools. However, using at least three blockchains can ensure reliable time sources that agree within an hour. The blockchain provides an approximate time source that gives a world-wide consensus without direct trust of any player, and it can be used to build time capsule applications that cannot be tricked into exposing their contents too early. The blockchain provides an extra piece of reliable data that is not being fully exploited by applications, which is the time agreed upon by more than 50% of participants with a strong financial incentive to keep it accurate within approximately 10 minutes. Bitcoin-level trusted time can currently be obtained by polling independent servers via HTTPS headers such as google.com, baidu.cn, and yandex.ru. However, miners have previously manipulated the timestamp to increase their gigahashes, and an application given a truncated chain can become stuck in the past. To prevent these issues, at least three block chains should be used to obtain reliable time sources that agree within an hour.In terms of using the blockchain as a reliable time source, one issue highlighted is that apps cannot tell if they were given a truncated chain. Nonetheless, cryptographic proofs can be reviewed, and the difficulty should be growing/declining only in a realistic manner up to the most recent block. It is possible to create a nonce, timestamp it, wait for confirmation, and get the merkle path to the block header to prove that an attacker has spent whatever resources it took to create a valid block. Building time capsule applications that cannot be tricked into exposing their contents too early requires a tamper-resistant execution environment with the correct system time.The security of breadwallet, an iOS application for Bitcoin storage, is based on block height rather than block timestamp, and pin-locked devices are secure as the filesystem is hardware AES encrypted to a combination of pin+uuid. Attaching to its process requires root access, making it more challenging than convincing the device to change its system time. However, the security benefits may not be too significant. The security benefits of breadwallet being tamper-resistant and zero-on-tamper hardware were questioned, and suggestions were made to attach a debugger or modify the program to ignore the block-sourced time. Nonetheless, since breadwallet is an iOS application, attaching to a process requires root access, making it more challenging than convincing the device to change its system time. Overall, the conversation highlights various security measures and challenges related to Bitcoin wallets and the blockchain. There is no clear resolution on the security benefits of recording time to disk or relying on the P2P network for PIN unlocking.
